messages: 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (17:28): Thanks for the heads up on case insensative selectors, zcorpan.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:35): wonders what client do people use for jabber.ietf.org meetings
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:35): Empathy
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:35): it ships with Ubuntu
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:36): and does pretty much all messaging
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:37): doesn't go to ietf meetings but uses bitlbee+irssi for jabber (donno if that has all the needed features for that usecase though)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:37): somewhat tempted to install the new Ubuntu beta
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:37): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: thanks
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:37): wonder if there's anything that works on OSX
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:37): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: it uses some extension, XEP-0045
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:38): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, http://www.pidgin.im/download/mac/ prolly works
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:38): thanks
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:38): was using pidgin before
73cc301f328d92a18944f8e1a0d91e72 (17:48): adiumx uses the pidgin lib
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:50): this is quite boring
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:50): iri meeting
71bd9426656c7068876f52fb7934af7f (17:51): i believe that
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:51): Not just anne dissing the channel
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:51): mumbling on Unicode, UTF-8, octet sequences
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:52): just some meta discussion on the presentation of a IRI vs a IRI
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:01): dunno, we're now at LEIRI and HTML5 URL...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:01): but it's going very slow
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:09): The concept of competition between validators would be more convincing if more than one validator existed
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:10): also isn't very inspired by how few web developers seem to use non-officially-endorsed tools like jslint, compared to Standards-Based Validators
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:11): Also it would be more convincing if anybody used the HTML4 validators that compete with validator.w3.org
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:11): (but as far as I can tell, everyone uses the latter)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:12): i've seen people use validator.nu
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:12): I tried using jslint once but then I realised it was a waste of time
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:13): and I was making my code uglier and less readable just to satisfy its rule for semicolons and for not using the same name with var twice in one function
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:13): s/rule/rules/

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:15): Also, for compiled languages, where it's common to use warnings, everyone just uses their compiler's built-in warnings, so there's little to no competition on that score per se.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:16): (although I guess quality of warnings might be a contributing factor in the decision on which compiler to use, if there are multiple realistic choices for your platform)
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:23): Are there any other vendor stylesheets out there?  Like, has someone compiled a stylesheet of how one browser does everything?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:24): Every browser has its own UA stylesheets.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:25): I thought a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 collected some for his guide thingy
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:25): I would love to get ahold of those.  I realized it might be a much more effective way to write mine.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:25): I've been doing it through a process of laying out a pangram of every element in html5, then applying the styles from the html5 rendering guide.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:26): the h:tml doc uses the Webkit default UA stylesheet
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:26): Then applying additional styles in a vendor css file to catch whatever else was needed to normalize them.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:26): http://svn.webkit.org/repository/webkit/trunk/WebCore/css/html.css
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:31): the pecurialities are interesting. epiphany-webkit for example, does not have a default styling for <i>
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:32): Thanks a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, 0__qem sure is a strange value.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:34): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132: I think that just gets interpreted as 0em
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:35): I think for the build of the h:tml doc, I have it stripping out the __q part
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:35): I don't remembering ever hearing what purpose the __q part serves
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:36): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:37): http://dev.w3.org/html5/markup/tools/css2xml
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:37): (if you care to see all the ugliness)
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:38): I do care, I'm very interested in seeing how uas style and how people are using this info

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:42): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132: Poke around in your Firefox install to find it's stylesheet.  I've modified mine for a few things.  Relatively easy to get to.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:42): Awesome!
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:42): Now just to get IE's
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:46): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: is that Yngve speaking?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:54): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, I dropped out
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:54): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, figured I should get some food
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:56): http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/firefox/nightly/latest-trunk/ "This page is in Irish.  Would you like to translate it? [Translate] [Nope]"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:56): I got bored with it too. All the high-level theoretical thought trains. How about starting with where contemporary implementations are?

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (18:58): Interesting how Firefox tightens up their css file (e.g. "margin: 1em 0") but then does "0px" and "margin: 0.5em auto 0.5em auto;" in other places.  It's nice to know these stylesheets are written by humans.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:00): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132: Or it's worrying to know these stylesheets were written by robots that can pass the Turing test
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:01): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, true dat, I am C.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:02): If we find IE's, my assumption is that it would pass with flying colors.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:03): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Larry is mentioning use of the term "URL" now
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:04): oh, maybe I should dial back in
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:08): Does IE actually use a default stylesheet that's a real CSS file, rather than something more ad-hoc and legacyish?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:12): I think even for Mozilla and Webkit, the default styling behavior (logic?) is not totally captured in their UA stylesheets
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:12): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, I would guess so for IE >= 8.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:13): But yeah, some things aren't specifiable in CSS.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:13): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, we could write one if they don't already have one.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:13): They also all use vendor-specific extensions in their UA stylesheets, I assume.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:13): For anyone who hasn't seen it yet, this is interesting: http://themaninblue.com/writing/perspective/2010/03/22/
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:13): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: some things are, but they don't specify them in the UA stylesheet for some reason
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:14): e.g., neither Gecko and Webkit UA stylesheets set bold on the th element
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:14): they do it in program code instead
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:14): Really?  Why?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:15): there may not be many (or any) more instances of that then the th case
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:15): but I know of the th case, at least, so I suspect there might be others
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:15): how long does this meeting go on for?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:16): I think it was supposed to be 2.5 hours
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:16): I'm cleaning up the stylesheets and placing them @ http://sandbox.thewikies.com/html5-browser-stylesheets/
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:17): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, kk
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:17): I wasn't sure what the version was on that webkit stylesheet, it was from their trunk, so I was going to add the version numbers once I know.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:17): now they're talking about vests vs t-shirts
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:17): clearly ninjas win
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:18): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132: note that those stylesheets get updated/changed somewhat regularly
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:18): so if you make copies of them, you are going to need to track the upstream changes
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:20): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, definitely the reason why I want to grab the versions.  Yea, I can always tag it 56629
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:27): Tagged them as firefox-v3.6.2.css and webkit-r56629.css
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (19:37): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132, better tag it gecko-1.9.xyz
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (19:37): after all its the rendering engines that change this
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:37): how would i verify whcih gecko it was?
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (19:38): doesn't ff report this ?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:38): btw, from what I understand MS IE saves their stylesheet in an xml file.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (19:38): check the about dialog.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (19:39): XML stylesheets, what a funny idea :D
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (19:39): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132, dunno. but i have iceweasel 3.5.8, which has 1.9.1.6, so it seems plausible
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:42): I found IE6's stylesheet!
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:44): Or I'm really dang close.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:44): res://msxml.dll/defaultss.xsl
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:46): That sounds like it's a stylesheet for XML files, not for HTML
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:46): given that it's in msxml.dll
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:50): Yea, just need to figure out what the dll is for html
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:50): http://sandbox.thewikies.com/html5-browser-stylesheets/defaultss.xls.txt
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:50): that's the one for xml, at least.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:55): HTML is lots of DLLs
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:55): like mshtml.dll
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (19:59): Yea ... it sure feels close though.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (20:02): According to http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa741312(VS.85).aspx it might be in mshtml.dll
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:03): There are no strings in that file that look like CSS to me
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:04): Maybe they're ROT13ed.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:04): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I'm pretty sure that most people that use jsLint turn of many of the more opinionated warnings
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (20:04): Maybe they're in the registry?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:04): and I don't think it's really comparable to HTML since javascript doesn't have any conformance criteria
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:05): Some people want that for HTML too, apparently.  Or at least are open to considering it.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:06): (I guess theoretically one might like a porgram that told you if you were going to hit any features that change behaviour in ES5 strict mode. But that probably isn't statically determinable)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (20:06): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Yes some people want it. That doesn't mean it's a good idea
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:19): Do all browsers support oninput?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:20): Meh, never mind.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:20): Doesn't matter.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (20:22): I found a hacky way to grab 'em all.
